user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__timeout:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__timeout (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                        const char *next_param)
{
  unsigned int param_value;
  enum PerfRepl_param_result value_res;

  value_res = get_param_value (param_name, param_tail, next_param,
                               &param_value);
  if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == value_res)
    return value_res;

  tool_params.timeout = param_value;
  return value_res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__timeout (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                        const char *next_param)

```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The function fragment does not call any <string.h> string-handling functions (it only calls get_param_value and performs an assignment). Therefore Rule 21.17 is not violated here. Note: if get_param_value internally misuses string functions and causes out-of-bounds accesses, that would be a separate violation in that function, not in this fragment.
